register.description: CAVLC Skip Run Count

bitfield.description: Fixed to 0. Writing this field is ignored. Reading this field returns always 0.

Skip run counter. Writing this field is ignored during MB processing. After MB processing, this field shows the updated value of skip_run_cnt. Writing this field can be possible between MB processes. The written value is reflected at the beginning of MB processing.

register.description: CAVLC Skip Run Count Shadow

bitfield.description: Fixed to 0. Writing this field is ignored. Reading this field returns always 0.

Skip run counter shadow register This register is copied with the value of CAVLC_SKIP_RUN_CNT.SKIP_RUN_CNT at the beginning of MB execution in CAVLC. Thus, when this register is read at the end of an MB execution ( MB N ), it contains that value of the skip run count that was valid at the end of the previous MB execution ( MB N-1 ). This register is to be used by S/W in H.241.

register.description: Debug Capability register. Used by debug software to determine which optional debug modules are present and how many instances of each module exist.

bitfield.description: Whether HWA Core Execution status and control is supported. 0 - Not Supported 1 - Supported
0 -Trigger Outputs are not supported 1 - Trigger Outputs are supported
The number of watchpoint modules that exist. The registers supporting the watchpoint modules must be implemented consecutively in the memory map
Number of Trigger Channels Supported 0x0 - No channels supported 0x1- One channel supported 0x2 - Two channels supported Others - Reserved
The number of counter modules that exist. The registers supporting the counter modules must be implemented consecutively in the memory map
Specifies whether HWA Core reset is supported or not which does not affect debug logic. 0 - Not Supported 1 - Supported
The number of breakpoint modules that exist. The registers supporting the breakpoint modules must be implemented consecutively in the memory map
0 - Trigger Inputs are not supported 1 - Trigger Inputs are supported
Specifies whether HWA Core supports SWBP or not. 0 - Not Supported 1 - Supported

register.description: Debug Control register. Used by debug software to control all of the basic debug functions

bitfield.description: Debug Restart Status bit. This bit is normally set when the DBG_HALT bit transitions from 1 to 0 when the natural execution state is entered. It is a sticky bit. It may also be set when a synchronous run causes the accelerator to leave halted state. - Reading 1 means HWA Core exited halted state (at least temporarily). - Reading 0 means HWA Core did not exit halted state. - Writing 1 shall clear the bit if set. There is no restriction on when it can be cleared. - Writing 0 shall have no effect.

0 DBG_HALT Global debug run control. The bit will be read as being set upon entry to HALTED state due to halted state being entered because of SWBP, HWBP, HWWP, EMU0 / 1 trigger or manual halt requested through this control. - Writing 1 when read 0 shall cause a halt on the next possible halt boundary. - Writing 0 when read 1 returns the system to the natural execution state. A synchronous run hardware request has the same effect. - Reading 1 means that the halted state has been reached or been requested by the manual halt mechanism - Reading 0 means that the target is in its natural execution state. NOTE: 1. The natural execution state means the FSM state entered prior to last entry into Halted state. 2. This would be the last application requested FSM state unless the DBG_SYS_EXE_REQ control was used to change it.
Execution halted due to single step completion - Set to 1 when the single step completes - Set to 0 when execution resumes
Status of EMU0 input. This bit indicates the current value of the EMU0 input
Execution halted due to trigger in on EMU0 input - Set to 1 when halt due to EMU0 input completes - Set to 0 when execution resumes
Status of EMU1 input. This bit indicates the current value of the EMU1 input
Execution halted due to register update of DBG_HALT - Set to 1 when halt due to DBG_HALT update completes - Set to 0 when execution resumes

Single Step Execution enable. When this bit is set, the accelerator core shall be halted upon execution of a single instruction. This is after the accelerator core has left the halted state by clearing the DBG_HALT control bit.
- Writing 1 enables halting when the next instruction following exit from halted state is executed. - Writing 0 disables halts via single step.
NOTE: 1. When the accelerator core enters its natural execution state, it may or may not execute an instruction and re-enter HALTED state.

EMU0 output control. The cross trigger output control. This values in this field determine the behavior of the outputs generated on EMU0.
NOTE: The effect of setting 1 is ignored if the HWA Core is currently in HALTED state until the HWA core exits and re-enters HALTED state.
0 : No output. Input only 1 : Pulse on halt. If this bit is set when halted then no effect until the HWA re-enters halted state. 2 : Pulse when any HWBP triggers 3 : Pulse when any HWWP triggers 4 : Drive pin high 5 : Drive pin low 6-15 : Reserved
Execution halted due to trigger from HWBP or WP. - Set to 1 halt due to breakpoint or watchpoint completes - Set to 0 when execution resumes

This bit enables the halts on watchpoint or hardware breakpoint trigger events. - Writing 1 enables halting on any hardware breakpoint or watchpoint trigger - Each breakpoint or watchpoint resource also has a local enable - Writing 0 disables halts via hardware breakpoints or watchpoints
The execution status of the module - Set to 1 when halted due to debug event - Set to 0 when execution resumes
EMU1 input trigger enable - Writing 1 enables halting on the falling edge of the EMU1 input - Writing 0 disables halts via EMU1 input
EMU0 input trigger enable - Writing 1 enables halting on the falling edge of the EMU1 input - Writing 0 disables halts via EMU0 input

register.description: Hardware Breakpoint Control for FE

bitfield.description: This bit configures the module to generate halt when triggered Writing 1 enables a HWA halt when triggered. The DBG_CNTL:DBG_HALT_BPWP must also be set for the halt to occur Writing 0 disables halt upon trigger
This is the local enable for the hardware breakpoint module Writing 1 to this bit enables the module to generate an instruction address match trigger Writing 0 to this bit disables the module
This bit is Set to "1" when HWBP located at the MB_Index in DBG_HWBP_n_MB_Index is executed Set to 1 when executing the MB index = DBG_HWBP_n_MB_Index Cleared to 0 by writing 1 to this bit

register.description: Buffer parameters and configuration for bit stream Note : In the non-frame decoupled configuration, this register is used for DRM configuration. The corresponding registers in BE are unused

bitfield.description: If '1', specifies "Direct Multi-page SL2 population" mode of operation

If '1', specifies SW interactive mode of operation. In this mode, the ECD5 does not interact directly with VDMA for bitstream DMA. Instead it triggers an interrupt for requesting DMA transfer of bitstream.
Number of pages in SL2
If '1', disables the triggering of VDMA. Only the SL2 buffer management is activated.
Size of each page in SL2 (in bytes); bits[3:0] are ignored, so the effective size is a multiple of 16 bytes

register.description: DMA Group ID for bit stream Note : In the non-frame decoupled configuration, this register is used for DRM configuration. The corresponding registers in BE are unused

bitfield.description: Group ID for VDMA transfer

register.description: Buffer Parameters and configuration for bin stream 0 Note : Valid only in frame decoupled mode

bitfield.description: If '1', disables the triggering of VDMA. Only the SL2 buffer management is activated.

Size of each page in SL2 (in bytes); bits[3:0] are ignored, so the effective size is a multiple of 16 bytes Although the VDMA transfer for bin stream is deterministic, PAGE_SIZE is needed by ECD5 to know when to trigger VDMA - i.e. when the page becomes full. Since the size of each entry/write in the bin buffer is not fixed, the DMA is triggered when the total size of the wriiten data reaches PAGE_SIZE
Number of pages in SL2
